AUTH-001.title: Splash Screen
assumptions: Users expect a brief brand moment before accessing the app
Returning users have valid session tokens stored locally
2-second delay feels intentional rather than slow
AUTH-001.userScenario: When I launch the app, I want to see the brand identity briefly, so I can trust I'm in the right app while it checks my login state.
pros: Establishes brand recognition before any interaction
Masks authentication check behind intentional animation
Routes returning users directly to home, skipping login
cons: Adds 2 seconds to every cold start regardless of urgency
No skip option for users who want faster access
AUTH-001.impactIfWrong: If 2 seconds feels too slow, users may perceive the app as laggy — would need to reduce animation time or add a loading indicator to show progress.

AUTH-002.title: Login Screen
assumptions: Users have existing accounts (email/password or SSO)
Demo mode with pre-filled credentials helps prototype testing
SSO partners (dm, PAYBACK) are recognizable to German retail customers
Users understand 'Forgot password' flow exists even if not fully implemented
AUTH-002.userScenario: When I return to the app, I want to sign in quickly with my credentials or partner account, so I can access my appointments and prescriptions.
pros: Pre-filled demo credentials reduce friction for prototype testing
SSO options surface partner integrations prominently
Password visibility toggle prevents typing errors
Clear path to registration for new users
cons: Demo mode badge may confuse stakeholders expecting production behavior
SSO buttons go to same loading screen — no differentiation yet
Forgot password link is non-functional in prototype
AUTH-002.impactIfWrong: If users don't recognize SSO partners, those buttons become confusing — would need clearer partner branding or explanatory text.

REG-001.title: Account Creation
assumptions: Users have a valid email address they can access
Standard password requirements (8+ chars, uppercase, number) are familiar
Users accept email/password as the primary auth method
REG-001.userScenario: When I decide to use MedAlpha, I want to create an account with my email, so I can access appointment booking and prescription features.
pros: Real-time password validation prevents submission errors
Visual checkmarks provide clear feedback on requirements
Step indicator sets expectations for registration length
Link to login catches users who already have accounts
cons: No social login option — email/password only
Password requirements may frustrate users with simpler passwords
No password strength meter beyond minimum requirements
REG-001.impactIfWrong: If users expect social login (Google, Apple), they may abandon registration — would need to add OAuth options.

REG-002.title: Email Verification
assumptions: Users have immediate access to their email inbox
6-digit codes are familiar from banking and 2FA apps
60-second resend timer prevents spam while allowing recovery
REG-002.userScenario: When I've entered my email, I want to verify ownership quickly, so I can proceed with registration without delays.
pros: Large input field with tracking makes code entry easy
Countdown timer sets clear expectations for resend availability
Email displayed confirms correct address was used
'Use different email' option allows error recovery
cons: Adds a mandatory step even for valid emails
60-second wait may frustrate users if code doesn't arrive
No alternative verification method (SMS, link click)
REG-002.impactIfWrong: If email delivery is unreliable, users get stuck — would need SMS fallback or magic link option.

REG-003.title: Personal Information
assumptions: Users are willing to provide full personal details during registration
German phone numbers start with +49 prefix
Address is needed for prescription delivery and appointment context
Date picker follows local date format conventions
REG-003.userScenario: When I'm setting up my profile, I want to enter my personal details once, so I don't have to repeat them for every appointment or prescription.
pros: Pre-filled +49 country code reduces input for German users
All fields on one screen reduces perceived registration steps
Explanation of phone usage builds trust for SMS verification
cons: Long form may feel invasive before users see app value
All fields required — no progressive disclosure option
No address autocomplete to speed up entry
REG-003.impactIfWrong: If users feel this collects too much data upfront, they may abandon — would need to defer some fields to later or make optional.

REG-004.title: Insurance Type Selection
assumptions: Users can identify whether they have public (GKV) or private (PKV) insurance
Users have their insurance card accessible to check if unsure
GKV users have NFC-enabled Gesundheitskarte; PKV users use GesundheitsID

REG-004.userScenario: When I'm setting up my account, I want to specify my insurance type, so I can access the correct prescription redemption flow later.
pros: Reduces confusion by explaining the practical difference (NFC card vs GesundheitsID)
Provides familiar examples (TK, AOK, Allianz) so users can pattern-match
Expandable 'Not sure?' helper prevents users from guessing incorrectly
Visual card design makes abstract insurance concepts concrete
cons: Adds a mandatory step even though most users know their insurance type
Users with dual coverage (e.g., supplemental private) may be unsure which to pick
Helper text relies on user having physical card nearby
REG-004.impactIfWrong: If users don't understand GKV vs PKV, they'll select incorrectly and face a broken prescription flow — would need to add a 'change insurance type' option in profile settings, or detect mismatch during first prescription attempt.

REG-005.title: GKV Insurance Details
assumptions: GKV users know their insurance provider name
Users can find their 10-digit insurance number on their Gesundheitskarte
Users accept €5-10 copay as standard for prescription medications
Users understand they'll need their physical card for NFC scanning later

Step-by-step explanation of prescription flow sets expectations
Copay acknowledgment checkbox prevents surprise charges later
Help icon suggests support for finding insurance number
cons: Provider list may not include all 100+ German GKV insurers
Insurance number input has no format validation
No card scanning option to auto-fill details
REG-005.impactIfWrong: If user's provider isn't listed, they can't complete registration — would need 'Other' option with manual entry or searchable dropdown.

REG-006.title: PKV Insurance Details

External link to learn more provides escape hatch for confused users
cons: Three prerequisites may overwhelm users unfamiliar with GesundheitsID

Button allows proceeding even without checking all boxes — soft validation only
REG-006.impactIfWrong: If users don't understand GesundheitsID prerequisites, they'll fail during prescription redemption — would need in-app onboarding or direct link to insurer app setup.

REG-007.title: Registration Complete
assumptions: Users feel accomplished after completing 5-step registration
Users want clear guidance on what to do next
Showing user data (name, email, insurance type) confirms successful registration
Primary next action is either exploring or booking immediately

pros: Celebratory checkmark animation creates positive emotional moment
User card with initials and insurance badge confirms stored data
Two clear CTAs: explore (low commitment) or book (high intent)
Insurance-specific next steps (health card vs GesundheitsID) are contextual
cons: No option to edit details if user notices an error
Success toast may be missed while animation plays
Back navigation unclear — can user return to previous steps?
REG-007.impactIfWrong: If user data was entered incorrectly, there's no immediate way to fix it — would need an 'Edit' link or clearer path to profile settings.

HOME-001.title: Home Dashboard
assumptions: Users want a quick overview of their healthcare status on launch
Promotional banners drive discovery of pharmacy features

pros: Surfaces next appointment prominently — reduces no-shows
Single prominent CTA for booking reduces decision paralysis
Auto-rotating promo carousel introduces features without overwhelming

No prescription status visible — users must navigate elsewhere
Recent activity section shows static placeholder data

BKG-004.title: Doctor Selection

BKG-010.title: Smart Match Confirmation

TH-002.title: Symptoms Selection

Six symptom categories cover most telehealth consultation reasons
Multi-select allows users with multiple concerns to indicate all of them
Symptom information helps doctor prepare before consultation
TH-002.userScenario: When I'm booking a video consultation, I want to describe my main health concern, so the doctor can prepare and prioritize accordingly.
pros: Checkbox-style selection allows multiple symptoms
Progress bar (1/3) sets clear expectation for wizard length
Pre-defined categories reduce typing on mobile
'Other' option catches edge cases not covered by categories
cons: Six categories may not cover all user concerns adequately
No free-text input at this step for users who want to describe specifics
Categories are broad — 'Pain/Injury' covers vastly different issues
TH-002.impactIfWrong: If users can't find their symptom category, they may select wrong option or 'Other' without context — would need more categories or symptom search.

TH-003.title: Symptoms Duration & Severity
assumptions: Duration and pain level are clinically relevant for triage
Users can accurately estimate symptom duration in days
1-10 pain scale is familiar from medical contexts
Slider interaction works well on mobile touchscreens
TH-003.userScenario: When I've selected my symptoms, I want to indicate how long I've had them and how severe they are, so the doctor understands urgency.
pros: Duration options cover typical telehealth timeframes
Visual pain slider with large number display is easy to use
Radio buttons prevent ambiguous selections
Progress bar (2/3) shows wizard progress
cons: Pain scale is subjective — 5/10 means different things to different people
No option for intermittent symptoms (comes and goes)
Slider requires precise touch — may be difficult on small screens
TH-003.impactIfWrong: If pain scale isn't calibrated to clinical expectations, doctors may misjudge urgency — would need reference examples for each level.

TH-004.title: Additional Information
assumptions: Free-text allows users to provide context not captured by structured questions
Photo upload is optional but valuable for visual symptoms (skin, injuries)
Users want to share relevant medical history before the call
Text area is preferable to voice input for most users
TH-004.userScenario: When I've described my symptoms, I want to add any additional context or upload photos, so the doctor has complete information.
pros: Open text field captures nuance not covered by categories
Photo upload checkbox indicates option exists
Progress bar (3/3) shows final step of wizard
Optional nature reduces pressure to provide lengthy details
cons: Photo upload is a checkbox, not actual upload functionality
No character limit guidance — users may write too much or too little
No voice-to-text option for users who prefer speaking
TH-004.impactIfWrong: If users expect actual photo upload and it's not functional, they'll be frustrated — would need real file upload or remove the option.

TH-005.title: Consultation Review
assumptions: Users want to verify symptom information before joining queue
Insurance coverage for video consultations is pre-verified
Edit functionality allows corrections without restarting
Consent is legally required before telehealth consultation
TH-005.userScenario: When I've completed the symptom wizard, I want to review all details before confirming, so I can catch any mistakes.
pros: All symptom data visible in scannable card format
Edit link enables corrections without restarting wizard
Insurance coverage callout removes cost uncertainty
Emergency disclaimer sets appropriate expectations
cons: 'Covered by insurance' is static — doesn't verify actual coverage
Consent checkbox text is long for mobile screens
No option to add or change symptoms from this screen
TH-005.impactIfWrong: If insurance coverage varies and users are charged unexpectedly, trust is broken — would need real-time insurance verification.

TH-006.title: Consultation Scheduled
assumptions: Users feel accomplished after booking confirmation
15-minute wait estimate is accurate for queue position

pros: Clear confirmation with estimated wait time
Two wait options accommodate different user preferences

Notification option reduces forced waiting
cons: 15-minute estimate is static — doesn't update based on queue
Notification option may not trigger real notifications in prototype
No option to cancel or reschedule from this screen
TH-006.impactIfWrong: If notification doesn't work, users may miss their consultation — would need reliable push notification infrastructure.

TH-007.title: Waiting Room
assumptions: Users want visual confirmation their camera and microphone work
Queue position and wait time help manage expectations
Camera preview builds confidence before call starts
Auto-advance to call simulates real queue progression

Hardware test buttons help troubleshoot before call
Preparation tip encourages optimal consultation environment
cons: Camera preview is simulated — no actual camera access
Queue position and wait time are static, not real-time
4-second auto-advance doesn't represent real queue waiting
TH-007.impactIfWrong: If camera preview shows nothing but real camera works, users may think their setup is broken — would need actual camera integration.

TH-008.title: Video Call

TH-009.title: Consultation Summary
